channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Deadly Missile Strike Hits Medical Clinic in Ukraine
item.description: A Russian missile hit the medical center in the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro, officials said, just hours after a heavy overnight assault on the surrounding region.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Belarusian military personnel took part in joint military exercises between Russia and Belarus last year.

item.title: Ukraine NATO Bid Mirrors West Germany’s During Cold War
item.description: West Germany joined NATO in 1955, choosing security over immediate territorial integrity. Some suggest the same path could be the best guarantee for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, delivering a video message at a Council of Europe summit in Reykjavik in May.

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Woos Voters in Re-Election Campaign
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has rock star appeal at his election rallies, promising to lead Turkey to claim its rightful place as a global power if he is re-elected in a runoff on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey campaigning in the capital Ankara in April.

item.title: How Turkey’s Erdogan Rose to Power
item.description: Turkey’s leader faced a criminal conviction, mass protests and a coup. Instead of hurting or ending his political career, they helped him accumulate ever more control.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan, accompanied by his wife, Ermine Erdogan, greeting supporters at the AK Party headquarters in Ankara, Turkey, this month.

item.title: Colombia’s Peace-Whisperer Makes Plenty of Enemies
item.description: Leyner Palacios’s push for dialogue, forgiveness and reconciliation has made him the face of peace in Colombia — and subjected him to death threats.
item.dc:creator: Silvana Paternostro
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leyner Palacios served on the Truth Commission, which spent four years examining Colombia’s internecine conflict, fought between 1958 and 2016.

item.title: Plane Door Opens in Flight but Jet Lands Safely
item.description: A man was arrested on suspicion of unlocking an emergency exit on an Asiana Airlines flight in South Korea when it was about 700 feet off the ground.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: An Asiana Airlines plane sitting on the tarmac after an emergency landing at Daegu International Airport in South Korea on Friday.

item.title: Four Killed In Shooting and Stabbing Attack in Japan
item.description: The assault on Thursday in the city of Nakano in central Japan took the lives of two women and two police officers. It was a rare episode of violence in a country where gun crime remains low.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Hisako Ueno

item.title: Inside Tina Turner’s Quiet Life in Switzerland
item.description: The woman from Nutbush, Tenn., renounced her American citizenship in 2013 to live a quiet life in Küsnacht on Lake Zurich.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Outside Tina Turner’s house in Switzerland on Wednesday. In Küsnacht, she did her own shopping and stood in line at the post office.

item.title: Australia Remembers Tina Turner With the Nutbush
item.description: The Nutbush, set to its eponymous song and sometimes considered an unofficial national dance, is popular with all ages and has taken on special significance after the singer’s death.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Tina Turner performing in Sydney in 1993. Her ties to Australia extend beyond the Nutbush.

item.title: Russia’s War in Ukraine, in Photos
item.description: A photographic chronicle of the second year of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.media:description: The 80th Air Assault Brigade of the Ukrainian Armed Forces firing rockets in the direction of Bakhmut on May 16.

item.title: Rwandan Genocide Fugitive Is Arrested After Being on the Run for 30 Years
item.description: Accused of having a direct hand in the killing of hundreds of Tutsis, Fulgence Kayishema was arrested in South Africa, where he hid as an asylum seeker.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The Kigali Genocide Memorial in Kigali, Rwanda, in 2019.

item.title: The Search for Madeleine McCann in Portugal Is Over, Police Say
item.description: A search of a reservoir in Portugal that came more than 16 years after the British girl went missing resulted in the collection of some material but did not solve the mystery of her disappearance.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Madeleine McCann went missing shortly before her fourth birthday.

item.title: Here’s Why So Many People Moving to the U.K.
item.description: Despite post-Brexit restrictions and government vows to control it, immigration to Britain reached an all-time high in 2022, driven by war, politics and economics.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian and British flags hanging outside a bar in Liverpool, England, in May. A large influx of refugees from Ukraine is one factor driving up immigration.

item.title: How Erdogan Reoriented Turkish Culture to Maintain His Power
item.description: Turkey’s president has made a spectacle of the Ottoman past, using monuments and TV shows to rally his voters. His cultural opponents have faced censorship, or jail.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:credit: Bradley Secker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, who is running for re-election on Sunday, has used culture as a lever of power during his two-decade rule.

item.title: The Counteroffensive Is Coming
item.description: We preview what is next in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: The 80th Air Assault Brigade of the Ukrainian Armed Forces fired a barrage of 122mm Grad rockets in the direction of Bakhmut during a night operation in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Vietnam Activist Jailed for Mocking Official’s Salt Bae Meal
item.description: A powerful Communist official ate a gold-encrusted steak in London. An activist who poked fun at the excess was sentenced to more than five years.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Chau Doan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Burhan Sönmez on the Tensions Between Politics and Art in Turkey
item.description: Burhan Sönmez, who is president of PEN international, discusses the tension between politics and art and the role of literature in authoritarian societies.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:description: Burhan Sönmezm, a writer who is part of Turkey’s ethnic Kurdish minority, sees the upheavals of the Erdogan years as only the latest chapter in an ongoing struggle of Turkish power and Turkish art.

item.title: Gasoline Prices, a Source of Pain Last Year, Have Come Way Down
item.description: Reasons include a stronger supply of oil and weaker-than-expected demand, energy experts say. Some people are saving hundreds of dollars on fuel.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: A gas station in Alexandria, Va., this week. Because gas prices are posted on big colorful signs, they can have a powerful psychological impact on consumers.

item.title: Restaurant Chain Franchises Face Scrutiny From the FTC
item.description: Troubles at the restaurant chain Burgerim highlight concerns about whether franchisees need more protection in their contracts with franchisers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Corkery
item.media:description: Franchises are ubiquitous in the American business landscape but concern is rising about the poor disclosure of business risks.

item.title: ‘Different Standards’: The Struggle of Indigenous Journalists in Australia
item.description: The departure of the TV host Stan Grant has set off a conversation about race and racism in the country’s media industry.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Stan Grant announced that he would step back from his television hosting duties after receiving “relentless” racial abuse.

item.title: Russia’s Wagner Mercenaries Say They'll Pull Out of Bakhmut
item.description: After seizing the city in eastern Ukraine after a long, brutal fight, the Wagner mercenary force is turning it over to the depleted Russian Army to defend.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Marc Santora
item.media:description: An image released by Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s press service that it says shows him with Wagner fighters in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Arctic Squirrels Have a Climate Change Problem
item.description: Climate change appears to be disrupting the hibernation of females in the Far North, scientists say, and that could affect mating season.
item.dc:creator: Mélissa Godin
item.media:description: An Arctic ground squirrel on the lookout. Researchers have found that females are emerging from hibernation up to 10 days earlier.

item.title: Man Arrested in Downing Street Car Crash in London
item.description: A man was arrested on “suspicion of criminal damage and dangerous driving,” but the police later said the episode was not being treated as “terror related.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Police officers stand guard near where a car crashed into front gates on Downing Street in London on Thursday.

item.title: Ron DeSantis and the ‘Scaffle’ Vote
item.description: As DeSantis announces his campaign, we dig into what may be the single most important fact about U.S. politics.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Photo illustration shows the live Twitter talk with Elon Musk with a background of Ron DeSantis as he announces his 2024 presidential run on his Twitter page, May 24, 2023 in Los Angeles, California.

item.title: Bou Samnang Lost Southeast Asian Games Race, but Won Praise
item.description: Video of the Cambodian runner Bou Samnang’s rain-soaked performance in a 5,000-meter race resonated with fans who applauded her gritty determination.
item.dc:creator: Sun Narin and Mike Ives

item.title: UK Net Migration Record Poses Sharp Dilemma for Sunak
item.description: Net migration to Britain has exceeded 600,000 a year, stirring tensions in a government that promised to stem arrivals.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sutton High Street in southwest London is now home to a number of Hong Kong families.

item.title: What to Know About Russia’s Capture of Bakhmut in Ukraine
item.description: Moscow has declared victory in its long, bloody assault. But a full capture of the ruined city may not help Russian forces advance deeper in the Donbas region.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops firing toward Russian positions near Bakhmut in March.

item.title: How Geena Davis Continues to Tackle Gender Bias in Hollywood
item.description: When it comes to quantifying bias in popular entertainment, the Academy Award winner’s in a league of her own.
item.dc:creator: Chris Colin
item.category: Davis, Geena, Institute on Gender in Media
item.media:credit: Magdalena Wosinska for The New York Times
item.media:description: Next year will mark two decades since the Academy-Award winning actor created the Geena Davis Institute on Gender in Media.

item.title: Russia is Modifying Soviet-Era Bombs to Use Against Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainian and American officials say Russian warplanes are dropping Soviet-era bombs, some modified to glide long distances, which are almost impossible to shoot down.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Emergency workers inspecting a FAB-500 bomb in Preobrazhenka, Ukraine, last month. The Russian military is also modifying bombs similar to these to become glide bombs.

item.title: Airports With the Worst Records for Cancellations and Delays
item.description: If you can, avoiding destinations with the worst records for delays and cancellations may be wise. Or at least time your arrival right.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Sims

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Celebrating the life of Tina Turner.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Tina Turner in concert in Los Angeles in 1984.

item.title: Fresh From Attack on Russian Soil, Raiders Taunt the Kremlin
item.description: The cross-border raid by Russian fighters based in Ukraine appeared intended in part to force Moscow to divert its soldiers from the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighters held a news conference in northern Ukraine on Wednesday after staging attacks in Russia.

item.title: USS Mannert L. Abele, Navy Ship Sunk in World War II, Is Found
item.description: The U.S.S. Mannert L. Abele was broken in half by two kamikaze attacks and sank in 4,500 feet of water, killing 84 sailors.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Mannert L. Abele was sunk in 1945 during the Battle of Okinawa.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: DeSantis’s Presidential Run
item.description: Also, China cracks down on comedy.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida enters the race as Donald Trump’s most formidable Republican rival.

item.title: Ukrainians Were Likely Behind Kremlin Drone Attack, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: American spy agencies do not know exactly who carried out the attack this month, but suggest it was part of a series of covert operations orchestrated by Ukraine’s security services.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Adam Entous, Eric Schmitt and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: The Senate Palace within the Kremlin wall in Moscow in May, after two drones exploded near its dome in the early hours of the morning.

item.title: Prigozhin Forecasts Disaster if Russia Does Not Move Into Total War Footing
item.description: Yevgeny Prigozhin has been ramping up pressure on Russia’s military leadership and extending his criticism to the country’s moneyed elites.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner mercenary group, in Moscow last month.

item.title: Why the ‘Rules’ of Politics Don’t Always Stymie Outsiders to the System
item.description: For decades, many voters grew accustomed to a certain set of norms that seemed to govern political systems like rules. But elite groups have lost the power they once had to enforce those norms, or decided to change their own behavior.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Donald Trump arriving to announce his campaign for president in June 2015.

item.title: Chinese Malware Hits Systems on Guam. Is Taiwan the Real Target?
item.description: The code, which Microsoft said was installed by a Chinese government hacking group, set off alarms because Guam would be a centerpiece of any U.S. military response to a move against Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Great Hall of the People in Beijing. Telecommunications networks are key targets for hackers, and the system in Guam is particularly important to China.

item.title: France Bans Short Domestic Flights, But Not Much Changes
item.description: A decree formalizing the measure, which was passed in 2021, is riddled with exceptions. Critics call its effect symbolic, at best.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: The new ban on short domestic flights has one huge loophole, among others: It carves out an exception for Paris Roissy-Charles de Gaulle Airport, one of Europe’s largest passenger hubs.

item.title: Rolf Harris, Disgraced British Entertainer, Dies at 93
item.description: His career as a musician and a painter over six decades ended abruptly when he was convicted of sexually abusing teenage girls.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: A 1964 album by Mr. Harris. He had several hit records in Britain and Australia, and his “Tie Me Kangaroo Down, Sport” reached No. 3 in the United States.

item.title: Brain and Spine Implants Allow Paralyzed Man to Walk Naturally Again
item.description: In a new study, researchers describe a device that connects the intentions of a paralyzed patient to his physical movements.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang

item.title: China Ramps Up Culture Crackdown, Canceling Music and Comedy Shows
item.description: Performances across the country were canceled last week after Beijing began investigating a stand-up comedian.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: The Beijing venue of the stand-up comedy company Xiaoguo Culture Media Co., which was fined around $2 million after one of its performers was accused of insulting the Chinese military in a joke.

item.title: 95-Year-Old Australian Woman Dies Days After Police Used a Taser on Her
item.description: Hours before Clare Nowland died, the police announced charges against the officer who used the stun gun on her in the care facility where she lived.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Australian Broadcasting Corp., via Associated Press
item.media:description: A still from a video showing Clare Nowland after a sky-dive in Canberra, Australia, in 2008.

item.title: Orcas Have Sunk 3 Boats in Southern Europe, Scientists Say
item.description: A small group of orcas is ramming into sailboats in waters off the Iberian Peninsula. Researchers say they do not know what is driving the unusual behavior toward boats.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Netanyahu Budget May Risk His Economic Legacy in Israel
item.description: Israel’s prime minister has long advocated a small state, free markets and benefit cuts. But his new budget is heavy on subsidies for the ultra-Orthodox community, whose political support he needs.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, left, speaking during the budget debate in Israel’s Parliament on Tuesday.

item.title: They Cuddled a Kiwi. New Zealand Said, ‘Stop That.’
item.description: Video of the national bird being handled by Miami zoo visitors caused an outcry in New Zealand. Even the prime minister weighed in.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A kiwi at a sanctuary in Auckland, New Zealand, in 2017.

item.title: A Year in Uvalde
item.description: How grief has warped the lives of the Uvalde shooting victims’ families and friends.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Lauren Jackson
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

item.title: As Protesters Die, Peru’s Security Forces Face Little Scrutiny
item.description: In Peru, investigations into the killing of protesters by security forces are often closed without any charges, undermining people’s faith in their government.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj and Marco Garro
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antonia Huillca at her farm in Apurimac, Peru. Her husband was shot and killed during a protest in 2015.

item.title: The Battle for Bakhmut Is Over. What’s Next for Russia?
item.description: Seizing the city took 10 months and untold lives. Most likely, analysts say, Russia’s exhausted forces will settle into a defensive crouch, preparing for Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Members of Ukraine’s 93rd Mechanized Brigade driving past destroyed vehicles on a road outside of Bakhmut on Friday.

item.title: Mawar Becomes a Super Typhoon After Lashing Guam
item.description: Island residents experienced howling winds and periods of intense rainfall, which left most of Guam without power. Officials had yet to assess the damage, but typhoon warnings remained in effect.
item.dc:creator: Josie Moyer, Mar-Vic Cagurangan, Mike Ives and Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Ukraine-Aligned Fighters Assault Russian Region of Belgorod for 2nd Day
item.description: The cross-border attacks by fighters aligned with Ukraine were an effort to force Russia’s military to divert troops from the front line, an official said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Valerie Hopkins and Michael Schwirtz

item.title: U.S.-Made Armored Vehicles Appear to Have Been Used in Attack on Russia
item.description: At least three of what appeared to be American-made tactical vehicles known as MRAPs were part of the cross-border attack. According to visual evidence, Russia captured two of them.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen

item.title: Mexican President Said He Told Ally Not to Worry About Being Spied On
item.description: The leader acknowledged that he had been told the government’s top human rights official was targeted by spyware, but sought to downplay the surveillance on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico said the government would not investigate the surveillance of Alejandro Encinas, the under secretary for human rights, because, he said, “we do not spy.”

item.title: ‘Time Shelter,’ by Georgi Gospodinov, Wins International Booker Prize
item.description: Georgi Gospodinov’s acclaimed satire, translated by Angela Rodel, is the first Bulgarian novel to win the prestigious award.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Georgi Gospodinov, right, and Angela Rodel, his translator, received the International Booker Prize for “Time Shelter” on Tuesday.

item.title: F-16 Training Planned for Ukraine’s Pilots
item.description: Ukrainian pilots have a lot to learn before they can start using U.S.-made fighter jets, but experts say it might take less time than once thought.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: F-16 jets in March over Poland. Training for Ukrainian pilots could take place there.

item.title: Boris Johnson Referred to Police Over Potential New Covid Breach
item.description: The former prime minister was fined last year while still the head of government for breaking Covid rules in 2020, one of a series of scandals that eventually led to his resignation.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain leaving home in March.

item.title: As Migration to U.K. Soars, Britain Targets Visas for Students’ Kin
item.description: The government, which has been mostly focused on asylum seekers crossing the English Channel, is now turning to limiting some pathways for legal migrants.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The British home secretary, Suella Braverman, said the number of dependent visas had increased by 750 percent since 2019.

item.title: U.S. Navy Steps Up Efforts to Curb Iran’s Ship Seizures in Strait of Hormuz
item.description: The United States is increasing patrols in the busy shipping lanes, where Iranian forces have taken two internationally flagged tankers in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An Iranian Revolutionary Guard speedboat watching an American warship in the Strait of Hormuz last week.

item.title: Who Are the Soldiers Behind the Free Russia Legion?
item.description: The unit has taken responsibility for a rare assault in Russian territory, and a member says it is just the beginning.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian soldiers with the Free Russian Legion training in February in the Kyiv region in preparation to deploy to the front lines.

item.title: The Madeleine McCann Case: Here’s What We Know
item.description: A new search in Portugal has brought the case of the British girl, missing since 2007, back to the headlines.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Portuguese and German officers continued their search on Wednesday at a reservoir near the area where British girl Madeleine McCann went missing in the Algarve region of Portugal in 2007.
